IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
Reporting: TFC Ingram: Body Worn Camera: Activated/// B-33 In-Car Camera: Not Activated
Assisting: Deputy Pizzi #585 (Frederick County Sheriff): Body Worn Camera: Activated
 
Defendant:                Meredyth Lea Haeme
D.O.B.:                       10/26/1979
Date of Arrest:           08/05/2023
Times of Arrest:         1526 Hours    
VA License #:            T6087032

*1 prior DUI-05/2020in Virginia*

TRAINING/CERTIFICATES:
I am trained by the Maryland State Police and the National Highway Traffic Safety
Administration to administer Standardized Field Sobriety Tests.
Vehicle Calibration is up-to-date
Certificate of Training – A.R.I.D.E. – Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement

Vehicle in Motion:
     On August 5, 2023, at approximately 1454 hours, I Trooper First Class J. Ingram #6663 of the Maryland State Police Frederick Barracks in Frederick County, Maryland was provided a look-out for a red Hyundai driving on the wrong side of the roadway, in the area of Woodsboro Pike and Glade Boulevard. The unknown caller stated the vehicle entered into the Rutter’s located at 9210 Woodsboro Pike, Walkersville, Maryland. The driver provided a Virginia registration UJY3579. Upon arrival, I observed a red Hyundai Velstor hatchback matching the description provided. I attempted three times to contact the unknown caller, however, they did not answer the phone. I observed the vehicle to be unoccupied. I looked through the driver’s side window and observed multiple bags and boxes in the back and front seat of the vehicle. I also observed a credit card with the name of Meredyth Haeme.

Personal Contact: 
            I entered the Rutter’s and began to look around. I observed a white female wearing a gray shirt, black leggings and flip-flops, began to walk my way. The female made eye contact with me and immediately turned to the right and walked in the opposite direction of me. I exited the Rutter’s and waited for the driver of the vehicle to return. I waited approximately a minute and the same female that I described above walked out of the Rutter’s. I observed the female having trouble keeping her balance and almost fell as she exited the Rutter’s. She began to walk towards the vehicle on the sidewalk, lost her balance and stumbled over into the parking lot. I asked the female if she was okay, and she stated, “yes”. I helped guide her back over to the sidewalk, asked her if she was the owner of the red vehicle, she advised “yes”. I again asked if she was okay, and she paused and stated “yes”. While speaking to the female she continued to be unable to maintain her balance and was unsteady on her feet. I advised her to sit on the curb to avoid falling. She sat on the curb and began to cry and state that she wanted to go home. I asked her if she took anything that I needed to be aware of, and she stated “no”. I asked her if she consumed any alcohol, and she replied “no”, and then began to cry. I asked the female if her name was Meredyth, and she stated “yes”. While speaking to Meredyth, I would note that she was unable to form complete sentences, she was slurring her words, her eyes were glossy and blood shot red. I asked her if she would like to be evaluated by the Emergency Personnel, and she advised that she would. I requested EMS to respond. The arrived and evaluated Meredyth, she refused medical treatment. While EMS was with Meredyth, I spoke to her mother by phone. Her mother advised that Meredyth was just released from treatment of alcoholism, and that her and Meredyth were just in an argument earlier today. While Meredyth was in the back of the ambulance, I opened the door and I immediately could smell a strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from Meredyth’s person. Again, I asked Meredyth if she consumed any alcoholic beverages prior to her operating her motor vehicle, and she advised, “no”. I advised that I can smell a strong odor coming from her direction, Meredyth, paused and stated she had some wine around 3am. I asked how many and she could not remember. She later stated that it was “maybe around 3-4 pm”, I want to note that around the time I was speaking to Meredyth it was 1500 hours. I made Meredyth aware of the time, and she stated it was approximately 3 maybe 4 hours ago, that she consumed some alcohol. I asked Meredyth to peform the three Standardized Field Sobriety test, she agreed. As Meredyth exited the ambulance and walked towards me, I would observe her unable to walk without losing her balance and she needed assistance when standing.

Pre-Arrest Screening: 
    The evaluation was performed on the Parking lot of 9210 Woodsboro Pike, Walkersville Frederick County, Maryland Rutter’s, on the side parking lot, away from the view of the customers and free from any parked or parking vehicles.  The surface was dry, level, and free from obvious debris. The weather was clear during the test. Lighting conditions consisted of the outside natural light.

I asked the following questions:
Medical Conditions – No
Injuries – No

    The first test given was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus. The tip of my ink pen was used as the test’s stimulus and held approximately 12-15 inches from Meredyth’s eyes. Meredyth was instructed to look straight ahead, keeping her head still while following and focusing on the tip of the stimulus with her eyes only. Meredyth was positioned in a manner to ensure any lights (sun) would not interfere with the test results. Meredyth’s pupils were equal in size and showed equal tracking. (6/6 Clues observed)

Displayed lack of smooth pursuit-Present in both eyes
Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation – Present in both eyes
Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees – Present in both eyes

    The second test given was the Walk and Turn. Prior to performing the test, I explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Meredyth was instructed to place her right foot directly in front of her left foot and touch heel to toe. Meredyth was instructed to place her hands at her side and to remain in that position until told to begin the test. Meredyth was advised to take nine (9) heel to toe steps on a straight line and to make sure her feet touched heel to toe on every step. Meredyth was advised to keep her hands at her side, keeping her eyes focused on her feet, and to count every step out loud. On the ninth step, Meredyth was instructed to keep her lead foot planted, and to take a series of small steps to her left into the starting position and continue the nine (9) heel to toe steps. Meredyth was instructed the second series of nine (9) steps were to be performed identical to the first series a second time. Meredyth was instructed that once she begins the test that she was not to stop walking until the test was completed, keeping her hands down by her side, looking down at her feet, and counting each step out loud. I asked if she understood the test, and she stated she understood.
 (8/8 Clues observed)

* Meredyth had on flip-flops, she advised she would be okay to perform the test in those shoes.*

Instructional Stage:
-Meredyth lost her balance during the instructional stage - She had trouble getting her feet into the heel to toe position and maintaining it.
-Meredyth began the test before I gave instructions.

Walking Stage (1st Nine Steps):
-Heel to toe-After the first 2 steps, she missed heel to two the remainder of the first steps
-Offline- She stepped off-line at step(s) 7 and 11
-Arms- Entire test she would use her arms for balance
-Number of steps- Meredyth took 25

Walking Stage (2nd Nine Steps): 
-Turn- Did not keep her lead foot planted and turn correctly
-Stopped- after she turned around, she stopped and stared at me, I asked her if she was done, and she began to walk back.
-Number of steps- Meredyth took 31 steps
-Heel to toe-Entire steps back, she missed touching heel to toe
-Offline- Meredyth stepped offline at steps 1,9,15,16, at step 23, she stepped back and then continued to walk forward. 

    The last test given was the One Leg Stand. Prior to performing the test, I explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Meredyth was instructed to stand with her feet together and hands down by her side, while the instructions were given. When instructed to begin, she was explained to raise the foot of her choice approximately six (6) inches off the ground. While her foot was raised, she was to keep her standing leg straight, watching her raised foot and to count out loud by thousands (one thousand-one, one thousand-two). Meredyth was advised to continue with the test until told to stop. Meredyth was asked if she understood the test and the instructions to which she stated that she understood the test. (2/4 Clues Observed)

Instructional Stage:
Meredyth did not display anything out of the ordinary during the instructional stage


Balance and Count Stage: Balanced on her right leg

Puts foot down- Meredyth lifted her foot and then would drop it down and leave it there.

PBT was offered. Meredyth refused.

PBT results: N/A                                                         PBT Serial number: 1405762

I had reason to believe Meredyth drove a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol:

Strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from vehicle and breath.
Eyes glassy and red.
Observed signs of impairment during the performed Standardized Field Sobriety Test.
Her admission of consuming an alcoholic beverage prior to her driving. 

Meredyth Lea Haeme was placed under arrest for Driving Under the Influence of Alcohol at approximately 1526 hours. Meredyth’s mouth was checked for anything at approximately 1526 hours. On August 5, 2023, I played the DR-15 audio Advice of Rights in English, to Meredyth at 1600 hours. Meredyth agreed to take the test. Meredyth was transported to the Frederick County Police Department and Corporal #450 Geiser with the Frederick Police Department administered the Intoximeter Test at 1643 hours. Meredyth results were .24 grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath.  Meredyth was issued the appropriate documents and citations and was released to her mother and stepfather at approximately 1720 hours.

Meredyth Lea Haeme was charged with the following through the Maryland Transportation Article: 

(1.) 21-902(a1i) Driving Under Influence of Alcohol.
(2.) 21-902(b1i) Driving While Impaired by Alcohol.
(3.) 21-902(a1ii) Driving vehicle While under the influence of alcohol per se
(4.) 21-901.1(a) Reckless Driving
(5.) 21-901.1 (b) Negligent Driving
(6.) 21-201(a1) Driver failure to obey properly placed traffic control device instructions

All events occurred in Frederick County, Maryland.

Case CLOSED with arrest.
